ai.summary: A demanding 16.2 km circular hike around Llyn Ogwen in Snowdonia, North Wales. The route combines steady uplifts with rocky tracks and occasional short scrambles, delivering extensive mountain and lake views. It requires good fitness, navigation ability, and suitable gear, as conditions can change quickly in the mountains.
ai.terrain_summary: Rugged highland terrain with rocky paths, exposed sections, short scrambles, wet boggy patches, and long ascents/descents around Llyn Ogwen. Expect uneven footing, loose scree in places, and weather that can change footing and visibility.
ai.safety_notes: Check weather and inform someone of your plan. Wear sturdy boots and dress in layers; carry a map and compass (or GPS) and know how to use them. Bring sufficient water and high‑energy food, plus a warm, waterproof layer. Avoid the route in dense fog, high winds, or icy conditions. Be aware of rockfall and ensure safe footing near the water; start early to ensure daylight hours. This is a long, strenuous hike best tackled by experienced hikers.
recommended_gear: Sturdy waterproof hiking boots with good grip
Weather-appropriate clothing (base layers, fleece, waterproof shell, hat and gloves)
Map and compass (and/or GPS) with route knowledge
Water and high-energy snacks (or meals for the full 16.2 km)
First aid kit and emergency whistle
Headlamp or torch with spare batteries
Extra layers and warm shell for sudden weather changes
Trekking poles (optional but helpful on uneven ground)
ai.best_seasons: Spring to autumn (roughly April–October) offers the most reliable conditions, with longer daylight and drier trails. The hike remains challenging in these seasons; winter or very wet months require more gear and experience.
